feed.title: 2012 Junos Anyone's Game
feed.subtitle: No one artist dominates the Juno nominations this year.

link.Abstract: Drake was several hours late for his Sundance Festival set Jan. 21, but the Take Care rapper had an excuse. A snowstorm. "I almost lost my life six times to get to this motherf*cker," he told the crowd. "My flight was delayed six hours." Well, OK then. Check out photos from his show.
link.title: Photos: Drake Does Sundance

content.div:
There are two ways to look at the 2012 Juno Awards nominations, which were announced in Toronto on Tuesday and will be handed out in Ottawa on April 1, with the main event hosted by an unlikely candidate, William Shatner.

On one hand, it's great to see so many deserving first-time nominees, including Saskatoon's Sheepdogs and B.C singer-songwriter Dan Mangan being recognized with multiple nominations. The new faces, close to 100 of them in all, represent the cream of the crop bubbling up from the next generation of Canadian recording artists.

But at the same time, things are not encouraging in some of the top categories. The field of album of the year contenders is especially weak, with two Christmas albums (by Justin Bieber and Michael Buble) competing against Nickelback's formulaic rock project, Avril Lavigne's lacklustre pop outing and Drake's blockbuster rap opus. Although Nickelback, Bieber and Buble sold well, Drake's is by far the best of the bunch in terms of creativity.

It's not like it was an off year for quality albums. One of the year's best, Feist's Metals, is relegated to the adult-alternative category, where you'll find four other great albums: Ron Sexsmith's Long Player Late Bloomer, Jenn Grant's Honeymoon Punch, Jim Cuddy's Skyscraper Soul and Cuff The Duke's Morning Comes.

A former Juno darling, Feist has three additional nominations to make up for being shut out of album of the year, including artist of the year, songwriter of the year and the year's best DVD for her project, Look at What The Light Did Now.

This year, no single artist is likely to emerge as the big winner. Instead of showering one act with a slew of nominations, there are six front-runners, each with four shots at Juno glory. Along with Feist, they include Drake, City and Colour, Hedley, Nickelback and the surprise entry, Dan Mangan. On the strength of his excellent album, Oh Fortune, indie rocker Mangan is nominated for best new artist, songwriter of the year, alternative album of the year and video of the year for his "Rows of Houses" clip.

At the other end of the fame spectrum is high-profile rapper Drake, who's also nominated for four 2012 Grammy Awards for collaborations he did with Nicki Minaj and Rihanna. Shut out of the Juno winners' circle last year, this time Drake will be heading to the ceremony with four nominations for his much-lauded Take Care album, including album of the year, artist of the year, rap recording of the year and the fan choice award.

Proving the power of a strong fan base, City and Colour, the post-hardcore songwriting endeavour by Dallas Green, scored nominations for fan choice, artist of the year, single of the year and songwriter of the year, while pop-punk outfit Hedley shows up in fan choice, group of the year, single of the year and pop album of the year. Both acts have legions of devoted young fans.

Less beloved is Nickelback, who will be trying to rally support for the fan choice award. Though often mocked for their sludgy rock and misogynistic lyrics, they're in the running for best group, single and album. Avril Lavigne, despite an uninspiring album and poor concert ticket sales, managed to reel in nominations for album of the year, pop album of the year, and is on the fan choice list.

The fan choice award, which is determined by public voting, could go to one of 10 artists, ranging from Deadmau5 to Justin Bieber to Ginette Reno. Last year's Juno (and Grammy) superstars, Arcade Fire, are also among the contenders.

The competition gets interesting further down the list. New artist possibilities are Alyssa Reid, Mangan, Diamond Rings, JRDN and Lindi Ortega. Vying for the best new group banner are some terrific bands, including Braids, Hey Rosetta!, Mother Mother, the Rural Alberta Advantage and Sheepdogs. Capping off a year that saw Sheepdogs win a contest to appear on the cover of Rolling Stone magazine, the shaggy Saskatoon rockers are battling it out in a top category, single of the year, and facing off against veterans like Sam Roberts and Sloan for rock album of the year.

The host city, Ottawa, is well represented in the roots and traditional, solo, category, with veteran singer-songwriters Bruce Cockburn, David Francey and relative newcomer Craig Cardiff among the nominees. The popular Ottawa blues trio MonkeyJunk has also scored their first nomination, up against David Gogo, Bill Johnson, Harrison Kennedy and Suzie Vinnick in the blues category.

There are several fine albums nominated in the category for roots and traditional, group, including recent releases by the Good Lovelies, the Deep Dark Woods, The Once, Wailin' Jennies and Twilight Hotel. Also vibrant is the crop of dance-recording nominees, including the Grammy-nominated acts Duck Sauce and Deadmau5, Toronto electro-pop newcomer Anjulie, Martin Solveig and Dragonette and Mia Martina.

The awards' newest category gives props to the best metal/hard music album of the year, with a field of nominees that includes the Ottawa-area band, F-- The Facts, as well as Anvil, Cauldron, the Devin Townsend Project and KEN mode.

Performers announced for the Juno broadcast include Blue Rodeo, Deadmau5, City and Colour, Feist, Hedley and Nickelback, with more to be added in the coming weeks.

entry.title: Interview: City and Colour Helping Fans Cope With Their Own 'Little Hells'

link.Abstract: On the eve of his Canadian tour, City and Colour's Dallas Green chats about how plumbing personal troubles for his music has struck a chord with fans.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: City and Colour's Dallas Green has made a career out of plumbing his personal troubles, and that's struck a chord with fans. "On one side I feel so blessed to have made a difference for these people because music has been such a big part of my life, but on the other side I wish they didn't need to go through things like that," says the songwriter.
link.title: City and Colour Interview

link.Abstract: Alexisonfire is no more. The band's George Pettit revealed the news August 5, writing that the group's guitarists Dallas Green and Wade MacNeil have left the group to pursue other projects.
link.title: Alexisonfire Flames Out After 10 Years; Band Members' Departure Led to Break-Up

entry.title: Photos: Drake Does Sundance

link.Abstract: Drake was several hours late for his Sundance Festival set Jan. 21, but the Take Care rapper had an excuse. A snowstorm. "I almost lost my life six times to get to this motherf*cker," he told the crowd. "My flight was delayed six hours." Well, OK then. Check out photos from his show.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: The day after ringing in 2012 in New York's Times Square, Drake jetted to Las Vegas to play a set at The Joint/Hard Rock Hotel & Casino. YOLO, right? We've got photos from the Jan. 1 show.
link.title: Photos: Drake Takes Care of Las Vegas

link.Abstract: Drake loves sweaters, but does he know how to "Take Care" of them? We've rounded up sweater-care tips that should make the Toronto MC proud.
link.title: Take Care of Your Sweaters -- With Drake!
